text:
Halloween season wouldn’t be what it is
without the undead.

And some might say the most spine-chilling
creature of that realm is the vampire.
(Splash)

Welcome to this week’s episode of Reactions,
where if today’s sinister being doesn’t

scare you, the chemistry behind how it came
to be just might.

When you think “vampire” some of today’s
most popular vampires might come to mind.

Attractive bloodsuckers with pale, sometimes
sparkling skin.

But in the 18th and 19th centuries, when European
vampire lore first really took off, they were

a bit more...morose and, instead of that crystal-clear
skin, they appeared kind of sickly with a
reddish complexion.

Vampires were often depicted as men from poor,
rural areas, who, after dying--often from

diseases like the plague--would emerge from
their coffins to wreak havoc on a nearby town,

sucking the blood of humans, turning them
into vampires as well.
So how did this folklore come about?
Possibly...disease.

Diseases that gave sufferers symptoms strikingly
similar to what we see in vampires--things

like pale skin, sensitivity to light, and
a predilection for...biting.

Most would say these connections are...speculative,
since medical records from hundreds of years

ago were non-existent or questionable at best,
but they’re still fun to think about on

a lonely winter’s eve, with some fava beans
and a nice chianti.

Let’s examine a few of our blood-sucking
friends’ most famous traits.

First, a constellation of vampiric symptoms:
Weakness and exhaustion, fangs dripping with

blood, an aversion to garlic, and sensitivity
to light.

A disease called congenital erythropoietic
porphyria, or CEP, causes many of these and--interesting

side note--it’s a disease that’s also
linked to werewolf lore, but we’ll have
to tackle that another time.

CEP is a rare disorder caused by a defect
in genes related to, appropriately enough,
your blood.

People with CEP don’t make as much heme--an
iron-containing molecule that makes it possible
for your blood to carry oxygen.

This causes their red blood cells to break
down, decreasing their red blood cell count

which, at the very least, would make them
feel exhausted.
That takes care of one symptom.

When you’re not creating heme, toxic compounds
called porphyrins build up.

That’s because heme is derived from these
compounds, which get their name from the Greek
word for purple.

When you're not creating heme, these deep
reddish purple porphyrins build up in your

bones... and in your teeth, creating a look
reminiscent of blood-covered fangs.
What about garlic?
This one is a bit more tenuous.

Certain compounds in garlic can increase activity
of an enzyme called heme oxygenase-1.
Heme oxygenase-1 breaks down heme.

And remember, if you have CEP, your levels
of heme are already extremely low.

The last thing you would want to do is eat
something that reduced them further.

However, this doesn’t fully explain why
vampires would be afraid of garlic.
To affect them, they would have to eat it.
And finally, the Sun.

Folklore is definitely split on this one but
most vampires seem to want to avoid the sun
at all costs.

Turns out, CEP may be able to explain that
too.
In people with CEP, the Sun can be dangerous.

It causes porphyrins to donate their electrons
to oxygen, and--with the help of an enzyme

called superoxide dismutase--form reactive
oxygen species like hydrogen peroxide, which

can destroy your cells and cause severe skin
damage.

And I mean severe, in some cases so much scarring
that it leads to a loss of facial features.
Now, let us take a brief historical tangent.

Because CEP is a rare genetic disorder you
may be wondering--if it’s so rare, how could
it have inspired vampire folklore?
Well it might not have always been so rare.
Why?
Because of inbreeding.

In the past, inbreeding--which was especially
common among royal families--brought to the
surface diseases you wouldn’t normally see.

In other words, we would counsel against marrying
thy cousins.
Back to vampires.

There was another disease that caused people
to shun the Sun: pellagra.

Pellagra is usually caused by insufficient
vitamin B3 -- also known as niacin, which

can be synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan
or found in most meats, and foods like brown
rice, sweet potatoes and peas.

Being sensitive to the sun is a hallmark of
this disease, but why still isn’t entirely
understood.

One might say we’re… in the dark… on
this one.

But perhaps the most famous trait of all...a
proclivity to bite and consume copious amounts
of blood.

There’s no well-defined disease that makes
people drink blood, but there is a disease
that causes infected creatures to bite: rabies.

To this day, rabies claims the lives of tens
of thousands of people each year.

And its symptoms are, in my opinion, more
terrifying than the thought of being face-to-face
with a vampire.

In addition to fatigue, fever, and intermittent
spells of panic, rabies can cause aggression--which

includes biting--hallucinations...seizures...coma
and...death.

Rabies is a virus that’s transmitted through
saliva when an infected animal bites or scratches
their victim.

Rabies will ruthlessly hijack a newly infected
animal’s brain, and when it does it often
makes them bite.

How the virus has this power isn’t entirely
clear, but it’s an unbelievably clever way
for it to spread to as many beings as possible.

Once rabies infects your cells, the virus
will quickly travel to your spinal cord and

brain, where it multiplies, all the while
ravaging your cells.

It then moves on to your salivary glands and,
ultimately, saliva.

Rabies can lay dormant for months, but once
you begin to show signs of infection, death

is already knocking--most people then die
within a week.

If left untreated, rabies is fatal almost
100% of the time.

Other vampiric symptoms from rabies include
a fear of water, a fear of mirrors, and insomnia.

While less common, when a person with rabies
sees water or their reflection in a mirror
their larynx might spasm.

Sometimes this causes their esophagus to tear,
making them cough up blood.

Vampires mostly wreak havoc at night, and
people with rabies aren’t exactly known
for sleeping.

Rabies damages your brain cells and causes
your brain to swell, and that will affect

regions of your brain that, in part, control
sleep.

Centuries ago, when vampire folklore took
flight, many of the resources we have now--like

foods that provide niacin, or a rabies vaccine--weren’t
as readily available, or just didn’t exist.

And maybe you’re wondering, what about other
vampire-esq traits?
Like blood dripping from a vampire’s mouth?

Or a belly full of blood after a night of
feasting?

Some have speculated that people created that
lore after looking at corpses that were naturally
decomposing.

When someone dies, blood can leach around
the sides of their mouth, and gas can accumulate

in their intestines, causing their stomach
area to swell.
Didn’t show that in Twilight.

We want to say a big thank you to Dr. Emily
Zarka for advising us on some of the vampire
lore for this video.

For more monsters, check out her PBS Digital
Studios series Monstrum, which we’ve included
a link to in the description below.

Are there other undead beings that you think
may hold some interesting chemistry?

Let us know in the comments and we’ll see
you next week.
